title: Analytics date picker labels are not centre aligned
description:
While adding the date picker for MR Analytics I noticed that the labels are not centre aligned.

This is because there is global css which is applying a bottom margin to labels.

![Screenshot_2020-10-01_at_12.10.46](/uploads/8d200e3985ca3feabd002ee566c93a89/Screenshot_2020-10-01_at_12.10.46.png)

This has been fixed for VSA by targeting `gl-daterange-picker label` in the page specific bundle, but we should implement a global solution.

We should also make sure that all of the margins are correct on mobile.

title: Improve `Projects::ContainerRepository::Gitlab::DeleteTagsService` logging
description:
## Summary

Follow up of my work on https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/40740.

Currently, [DeleteTagsService](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/services/projects/container_repository/gitlab/delete_tags_service.rb) is geared with some logging *and* a timeout support to limit its execution.

If the timeout is hit, we don't log how many tags have been deleted which is still a valuable information. It's not like the service was not able to delete any tag, it's just it didn't have time to delete all of them and so, it deleted only a few of them.

## Improvements

* Return the tags deleted no matter what kind of `result` is returned (`success` or `error`)

## Risks

* Low: we're only modifying the logs statements not the feature itself. In the worst case, we don't have the logs the way we want which is not a major issue and it's easily fixable.

## Involved components

* [DeleteTagsService](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/services/projects/container_repository/gitlab/delete_tags_service.rb)

title: Calculate checksum of an archived build trace
description:
## Description

We have implemented a robust correctness verification mechanism for cloud native build logs. It validates that the chunked I/O mechanism we used to persist build logs works correctly. After a build is done, however, we also merge chunks and send them to object storage. In itself it is much more simple operation than chunking traces, but we might want to validate correctness of this operation too.

We should also validate if build log has been properly archived after X time from build completion.

We should also check if this operation has not left orphaned build trace chunks in the database.

## Proposal

Add CRC32 / CRC32c / MD5 validation of merging and archiving a build trace.

- compute checksum for the build trace(this is done)
- store the checksum into `ci_build_trace_metadata` table
- find a way to extract the checksum returned by GCP when uploading the archived trace file
- store the checksum from GCP into the metadata table
- extend this mechanism to support different cloud providers

title: Truncate vulnerability evidence summary to a maximum length
description:
### Problem to solve

DAST vulnerabilities contain `evidence.summary`. The evidence is produced by ZAP vulnerability checks to help the user determine whether or not the vulnerability is a False Positive.

Examples of evidence include hashed values, cookie values, credit card numbers, and HTML elements (e.g. the form element missing an anti-csrf token).

As HTML elements can be included in the summary, the summary can be very large. An example of this occurring is when the HTML element in question is an inline `<script>` that contains a lot of JavaScript. In these cases, the value gained by storing large amounts of text is not worth the cost of storing or displaying it.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### Proposal

- `evidence.summary` should be truncated to `500` characters (500 is an arbitrary limit)
- If truncated, the summary should end with `[truncated]`

### What is the type of buyer?

[Gold/Ultimate](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/pricing/#four-tiers)

### Links / references

- [Periscope image of DAST JSON reports](https://app.periscopedata.com/app/gitlab/749790/Secure-Software-Composition-Analysis-Dashboard?widget=9858893&udv=0)
- [Internal Slack conversation](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C8S0HHM44/p1601389982135300)
- [Internal Slack conversation](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CKWJP0ZS7/p1601496358015400)

title: Vulnerability Report Activity filter
description:
### Release notes

Vulnerability Reports are often the primary way security teams triage and manage vulnerabilities. The current filtering and sorting options provide quick ways to focus the list view on a subset of vulnerabilities for more efficient workflows. You can also see any vulnerabilities that have associated Issues or which subsequent scans indicate are resolved. This Activity column indicates at a glance which vulnerabilities might be ready to close out, which are in progress, and which ones might need some attention. However, this column was not one you could filter or sort on.!

You will now have even more control of your Vulnerability Report experience with the introduction of an Activity filter. Available in the Project, Group, and Security Center Vulnerability Reports, this new filter allows you to view vulnerabilities with Issues that are not yet resolved, that are resolved but have no associated Issues, that have Issues and are resolved, or that have no activity. The available filter options are mutually exclusive sets, allowing you to drill into precisely the vulnerability list view you need for any task.

https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/vulnerability_report/

[Screen_Shot_2021-02-10_at_6.10.30_PM](/uploads/3903f5deedb3d1397874165abf798c83/Screen_Shot_2021-02-10_at_6.10.30_PM.png)

## Design (from Figma)
See [Design Issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/222447) and parent Epics for details.

| Columns/Tooltips | Filter |
| - | - |
| ![image](/uploads/fbaae156ef03bdcbde0af2b9e6945fdd/image.png) | ![Screen_Shot_2020-09-11_at_9.30.07_AM](/uploads/d72f03327fb2c23ebcff6415b11b8d3d/Screen_Shot_2020-09-11_at_9.30.07_AM.png) |

## Proposed Behavior

To keep this simple and moving forward, let's go with the following for now:

* Selecting the `All` and `No activity` options will unselect all other options
  * `All` effectively turns off this filter and displays all vulnerabilities according to the other filter values
  * `No Activity` will only show vulnerabilities that do not have Issues and are still unresolved
* Selecting `With issues` or `No longer detected` will unselect `All` or `No activity`.
* You can select both `With issues` AND `No longer detected`. In this case, you will only see vulnerabilities that match both criteria.

To help distinguish that the Activity filter behaves differently from the other filters, we will change the checkmarks next to `With issues` and `No longer detected` to checkboxes (`All` and `No activity` will remain as checkmarks\`). We can revisit the UX in a follow up issue after everyone is back from the holiday break.

## Implementation Plan

- [ ] ~frontend update the filters to add a filter for activity
    - [x] Since these filters are static, I believe this involves just adding the filter to `ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/helpers.js` and an update to the graphql query to filter by activity.
    - [x] the GraphQL query has been updated to take two more parameters `hasIssues` and `hasResolution`
    - [x] so the following filters should use the following parameters:
        - `All`: `hasIssues` = `null` and `hasResolution` = `null`
        - `No activity`: `hasIssues` = `false` and `hasResolution` = `false`
        - `With issues`: `hasIssues` = `true` and `hasResolution` = `false`
        - `No longer detected`: `hasIssues` = `false` and `hasResolution` = `true`
    - [ ] treat the `No activity` filter like the `All` filter (i.e. if `No activity` is selected, all other options are unselected, if another selection is made, `No activity` is unselected)

Related to #230381

title: spec/controllers/projects/releases/evidences_controller_spec.rb:168 only passes on retries
description:
I believe the test at spec/controllers/projects/releases/evidences_controller_spec.rb:168 is broken, and only passes on retries.

1. First try:
   - `release.id == 1` and `evidence.id == 1`
   - The evidence is found since auditors are allowed to see private issues.
   - The `SELECT "evidences".* FROM "evidences" WHERE "evidences"."release_id" = $1 AND "evidences"."id" = $2 ORDER BY "evidences"."created_at" ASC LIMIT $3 [["release_id", 1], ["id", 1], ["LIMIT", 1]]` query returns the evidence, failing the first test attempt.
   - I believe the auditor behavior changed (or maybe it's broken from the beginning!).
1. Second try:
   - Now `release.id == 2` and `evidence.id == 2`.
   - The `SELECT "evidences".* FROM "evidences" WHERE "evidences"."release_id" = $1 AND "evidences"."id" = $2 ORDER BY "evidences"."created_at" ASC LIMIT $3 [["release_id", 1], ["id", 2], ["LIMIT", 1]]` query cannot find the evidence.
   - Note the wrong `release_id` here!
   - I believe this is **because `release` is memoized in the controller**, and since the controller instance isn't reloaded on retries, `release.evidences.find(params[:id])` look for the `evidence` with ID 2 attached to the release with ID 1. => :boom: 
   - The test passes, but not for the reason expected!

This can be reproduced with `RETRIES=1 bin/rspec spec/controllers/projects/releases/evidences_controller_spec.rb:168`.

I believe we could disable retries for controllers and detect broken tests like that...

title: Add support for search and including project labels within Group Labels API
description:
# Summary

Currently in Group context, we use private API (eg; `/-/labels.json?include_ancestor_groups=true`) to fetch labels which includes all the labels in the response. This is the case for labels dropdown in sidebar for Issues, MRs and Epics.

This has also been a performance problem for a while as now we have over 1000 labels for `gitlab-org` group in GitLab.com. As we're migrating labels dropdown to [`labels_select_vue`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/vue_shared/components/sidebar/labels_select_vue/) across GitLab, it would be sensible to make the dropdown use Public API and perform searching of labels an async action (we're already doing it for Epics and Milestones dropdown currently).

Currently, both [Group Labels API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/group_labels.html#group-labels-api) & [Project Labels API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/labels.html) lack support for `search` param. Additionally, Group Labels API doesn't support including project labels (via `include_project_labels` param for example), so we need to update both these endpoints to have `search` support and Group Labels API specifically to have project labels fetching support.

title: UX: Add reassurance to the trial flow. On registration page or higher up in the funnel.
description:
## Problem 

Before starting a trial I am presented with very few reassurance during the process. It is not very clear what value I can get starting a GitLab trial v.s sign up for GitLab without starting a trial. As a result of this, taking an informed decision is harder to do. 

## Input data

#### Personas
* [Buyers personas](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#buyer-personas).
* [Product manager](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager).
* [Development team lead](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead).
* [Systems Administrator](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator).

## Solution

Adding reassurance before users enter the trial flow is likely to help them in their decision making process which would correlate with an increase in trial started. This can be either on the [trial registration](https://gitlab.com/-/trial_registrations/new?glm_source=about.gitlab.com&glm_content=free-trial) page or higher up, on the [free trial page](https://about.gitlab.com/free-trial/) of the marketing website.
Example of reassurance:
* Social validation: Leveraging our case study to demonstrate how companies improve their DevOps with GitLab, use quotes from GitLab users, pull content from [Is GitLab any good?](https://about.gitlab.com/is-it-any-good/). 
* Better emphasis on "no credit card required".
* Better emphasis on the features that the trial offer and how valuable they are for some of our customers.

## Solution Validation

We will validate the solution using A/B testing and monitoring any qualitative feedback that we can get from external sources or through the GitLab forum.  

## Proposed design
![Trial-register-desktop](/uploads/648460af5727ded11f2bb94b32dce4c2/Trial-register-desktop.jpg)

epic.title: [UX] Add reassurance to the trial flow. On registration page or higher up in the funnel

title: UX: Add a progress bar in the trial flow
description:
## Problem 

When users are entering the trial flow they are presented with a series of steps and forms to complete before activating their trials one of the step title is "Almost there". Although reassuring, it is not fully clear how many steps are needed to complete this flow which might lead user to quit the trial process.

## Solution

We could add a progress bar within the trial flow to indicate the progress users are making. This would make the number of step to complete more transparent and trigger a need for closure. Ideally this would also reflect in the number of trial started.

## Validation

We will validate the solution using A/B testing and monitoring any qualitative feedback that we can get from external sources or through the GitLab forum.  

## Proposed design (TBD)
We should use the proposed design from the following issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/growth/ui-ux/-/issues/71.

title: DAST customers should be able to specify the name of their session token
description:
### Problem to solve

Customers who want to scan their site using an authenticated scan specify username/password using `DAST_USERNAME`/`DAST_PASSWORD`. In a traditional website, a session is created server-side, and a session ID is added to the user's cookies so that it can be passed with every HTTP request and used for matching to the authenticated session.

If a customer has a non-standard name for their session, then their scan will never be authenticated. This issue gives the user control by letting them decide the name of their session cookie.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### User experience goal

Customers should be able to run a DAST authenticated scan on their website.

### Proposal

- Customers can set the name of their token using `DAST_SESSION_TOKEN_NAME`
- The token name is added to the ZAP enabled HTTP session token names using the ZAP API
- GitLab DAST documentation is updated to include the configuration value
- Please add an end-to-end test that tests authentication with a non-standard name
- The `14.0` release should remove the `_gitlab_session` from the default acceptable token names
  - Communicate to AppSec, request they change it
  - Add to the list of items in `14.0`

### How come this works already for DAST scans against GitLab?

Hard coded in the DAST code repository:

```python
# Create a new session using the aquired cookies from the authentication
zap.httpsessions.add_session_token(target, '_gitlab_session')
```

### Session token names that are accepted by default

![Screen_Shot_2020-09-30_at_12.41.42_pm](/uploads/767ced4b6dbe44fb44c9c700a7366f8d/Screen_Shot_2020-09-30_at_12.41.42_pm.png)


### What is the type of buyer?

[Gold/Ultimate](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/pricing/#four-tiers)

title: Geo: Sync expired (but not yet deleted) artifacts
description:
## Problem

- Have DB replication lag of more than 1 second (I am assuming this was the case, which helped surface a race condition)
- Trigger jobs which create artifacts which expire in 1 second

The artifacts never get synced to the secondary, even though you can still browse and download the artifacts on the primary.

#### What is the behavior of expired artifacts?

The job on the primary says: `These artifacts are the latest. They will not be deleted (even if expired) until newer artifacts are available.`. So, expired artifacts does not equal deleted artifacts.

## Proposal

Should expired artifacts be synced by Geo secondaries? They haven't been since 11.0, but it was to resolve failures when attempting to sync expired artifacts https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/5357.

We could cause them to be synced by removing `not_expired` from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/v13.4.1-ee/ee/app/models/ee/ci/job_artifact.rb#L80

~~I assume this is safe since if/when they do get deleted from the primary, a delete event will occur and be processed by secondaries.~~ We probably need to fire more delete events from the primary e.g. from services that cause mass deletion of artifacts. => This is now covered by https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/297472

I think this would make secondaries more accurate representations of the primary.

<details>
<summary>This is no longer relevant to this issue</summary>

**Update:** See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/258918#note_484092073 and https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/297472

## A minor related problem

If the expiration is longer so the artifacts become synced, when artifacts do expire, they are not deleted, so no delete event is processed. The background workers on the secondary eventually discover the expired artifact and delete it (but they do not delete the file since delete jobs triggered by this process are not given the file path, and then the delete job just deletes the registry). If/when the artifact is deleted on the primary, the delete event happens but the way `FileRegistryRemovalService` is written, it exits without deleting the file if there is no registry.

Summary: Artifacts become orphaned on secondaries after expiration.

I don't want to create a separate issue yet for this problem since it would be resolved by removing the `not_expired` scope.
</details>

title: Closed iterations still show in issues detail
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

Iterations that are already closed with past dates still show when selecting an iteration for some issue.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create an iteration
2. Wait until it closes (after due date)
3. Create a new issue
4. Save issue
5. Access details of issue
6. Search for iterations
7. Notice the closed iteration still shows, different than a milestone, that only opened and upcoming shows.

This is a problem, since there will be "tons" of closed iterations, and it will be very hard to search for the opened/upcoming ones.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Closed iterations show in list for assignment in an issue.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Only opened and upcoming iterations should appear on the list.

### Proposal

We already support adding a `state` parameter to the `iterations` GraphQL object, so all that has to happen is for us to change the query being used to populate the dropdown to send `state: "opened"`, which would return all `upcoming` and `started` iterations.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![image](/uploads/acb90cf8963a18dbc817511701b2d6f2/image.png)  
![image](/uploads/5371c99b52fb114a3f269dc2b63ead62/image.png)

title: Remove target reset to host
description:
# Context

Follow-up from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast/-/merge_requests/312#note_419909567

The ZAP scripts reset the provided target to its host. For example, if ZAP is given the target `http://vulnerableapp.com/WebGoat/attack`, it will reset it to `http://vulnerableapp.com` before spidering and scanning it

This functionality was migrated to DAST during the [ZAP script migration](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3364), but it's not clear if it is necessary or desirable.

# Proposal

Implement a new environment variable `DAST_SPIDER_START_AT_HOST` as a boolean configuration option, where `true` would reset the target to the host and `false` would start the spider at the specified path. The default option would be `true` for now, to keep current DAST scans testing with the same context that they currently have.

# Implementation plan

- [x] Add `DAST_SPIDER_START_AT_HOST`: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast/-/merge_requests/317
- [x] Add docs for `DAST_SPIDER_START_AT_HOST` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/45567
- [x] Create follow-up issue to make `DAST_SPIDER_START_AT_HOST` default to `false` in %"14.0": https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/267403

title: [VSA] Apply filters to the "Tasks by type" (previously  "Type of Work") chart
description:
### Problem to solve

On group-level Value Stream Analytics, the "Type of Work" chart is not affected by the filters set at the top of the page.  Users [would like it to be](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/249803#type-of-work-is-not-super-useful-for-providing-actionable-insights).

### Proposal


1.  On group-level VSA, the "Type of Work" chart will inherit the `filters` from the filter bar (like they apply to the stage data at the top of the page).  
1. The chart will also inherit the `date_range` for the top VSA filter bar.
2. Remove the label filtering for the type of work chart.
3. Leaving only the `Show` option of choosing: ``issues`` / ``merge requests``.
4. When there are no labels selected in the filter bar, display the top 10 labels by default (current behavior).

![Screen_Shot_2022-04-06_at_15.08.56](/uploads/fb8a6458353d818c54e64024b8553f3f/Screen_Shot_2022-04-06_at_15.08.56.png)

### Acceptance Criteria

1. Select these labels in the filter bar: ~"type::bug" ~"type::feature" ~"type::maintenance". 
2. The chart will shows a cumulative count of issues and merge requests breakdown to bugs, features and maintenance.  

### Future steps

In the future, we need to save filter sets so users can switch between them easily. We can have 3 predefined filters:

1. Type labels - bug/feature/debt breakdown
1. Priority labels
2. Group labels

### Related links

- [Next Prioritization Working Group - Taxonomy: Work types
](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1TDswR4h-Zo-Fdq3yVtk-q-uJrKe_03iF9jB1XQWqQb4/edit#slide=id.g123cae89002_0_19)
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217943#note_346421179
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/222449#note_361637084
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/249803#type-of-work-is-not-super-useful-for-providing-actionable-insights
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/349793

title: Vulnerabilities not always sorted by severity in Dependency List
description:
The vulnerabilities listed in the Dependency List aren't always sorted by severity; for instance, `Critical` vulnerabilities can be listed _after_ `High` ones (see screenshot below).

I think the original intention was to sort by severity: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/10077#note_178544237.

## Screenshot

![flameshot_2020-09-29_14-23-16](/uploads/7ca34f4f43175cdd01196a8e1e70a414/flameshot_2020-09-29_14-23-16.png)

## Implementation plan

Sorting happens in [Dependency List Service](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/ef62291fe51d2c8267f7fc1a16c6787cdc641e3f/ee/app/services/security/dependency_list_service.rb). This sorting algorithm assumes that vulnerabilities associated with dependency are already sorted. But with recent changes to the parsing function, that's no longer true and is needed to be fixed.

1. Add tests to cover cases for unsorted vulnerabilities for one dependency.
1. Update the sorting method to sort vulnerabilities in dependencies first.

## Example project

https://staging.gitlab.com/secure-team-test/dependency-list-test/-/dependencies

title: [Feature flag] Enable `View the environment that generated the alert`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## What

Remove the `:expose_environment_path_in_alert_details` feature flag

## Owners

- Team: @gitlab-org/ci-cd/progressive-delivery 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_progressive-delivery`
- Best individual to reach out to: @agulina 

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

When the Feature Flag is remove, the Environment Path will be available and visible in the Alert Details. We expect the possible following 3 scenarios to happen:

| A | B | C |
|-|-|-|
| `environment` is queried from `graphQL` | `environment` is queried from `graphQL` | `environment` is queried from `graphQL` **but it's `null` for some reason** |
| `path` is returned and it's a `string` | `path` is **`null` for some reason** |
| The page has the environment displayed (in the table, [environment is above details](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/232492#proposal)) | The page looks as in `B` but the name of the environment is not a link | The page will not display the environment in the summary but it will have an empty row in the table |
| ![Screenshot_2020-09-29_at_19.50.43](/uploads/cb13b72ee0bead699004e8050de63aa0/Screenshot_2020-09-29_at_19.50.43.png) |![Screenshot_2020-09-30_at_18.33.16](/uploads/8121cd5bd22abd04c1b8bbbb23801afe/Screenshot_2020-09-30_at_18.33.16.png) |![Screenshot_2020-09-29_at_19.01.04](/uploads/d65d12f1b8f976d99ad4c21c1b207c3a/Screenshot_2020-09-29_at_19.01.04.png) |

### What might happen if this goes wrong?


### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->

## Beta groups/projects

If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example.

- `https://gitlab.com/gitlab-examples/ops/incident-setup/everyone/tanuki-inc/` project

## Roll Out Steps

- [x] Enable on staging (`/chatops run feature set expose_environment_path_in_alert_details true --staging`)
- [x] Test on staging
- [x] Ensure that documentation has been updated
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com for individual groups/projects listed above and verify behaviour  (`/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab expose_environment_path_in_alert_details true`)
- [x] Coordinate a time to enable the flag with `#production` and `#g_delivery` on slack.
- [x] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com by running chatops command in `#production` (`/chatops run feature set expose_environment_path_in_alert_details true`)
- [x] Cross post chatops Slack command to `#support_gitlab-com` ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#where-to-run-commands)) and in your team channel
- [x] Announce on the issue that the flag has been enabled
- [x] Remove feature flag and add changelog entry
- [x] After the flag removal is deployed, [clean up the feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) by running chatops command in `#production` channel

title: Fix MR "Commits" tab counter not updating
description:
This an actionable insight from the [Code Review FY21-Q2 Category Maturity Scorecard](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/ux-research/-/issues/941) research ([insight](https://dovetailapp.com/projects/ac5e32e9-616d-4ddd-a1bb-1eb49084fe4e/insights/present/cfc739fa-315c-480b-80aa-2568e3fac93f)).

### Summary

When a commit is pushed, sometimes the counter in the “Commits” tab of a merge request is not updated at the same time as the list. In one research session, a participant saw 6 commits listed in that tab, but the tab counter said “5”.

![image](/uploads/f45dfe23ffa8f4babc6a5db5b4ca08bc/image.png)

### Steps to reproduce

1. Edit a file in an MR and commit your changes
1. Come back to the MR and notice that the Commits tab counter has not increased
1. Refresh the page, and the commit counter has increased correctly

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/pedroms/public-project/-/merge_requests/10/commits

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

When pushing commits, the Commits tab counter in the MR takes some time to update, even though the list shows the correct number of commits.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The Commits tab counter should update as soon as a commit is made, especially if the change was made through the UI.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![CleanShot_2020-09-29_at_11.37.07](/uploads/460e59b7245ff34c2b7d5863502849d1/CleanShot_2020-09-29_at_11.37.07.mp4)

### Proposal

* Add an extra request on page load to an endpoint to get the accurate commit count ([Public API endpoint available](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/merge_requests.html#get-single-mr-commits) or use a custom one to be provided)

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

title: Rake `gitlab:db:drop_tables` should also drop views
description:
The intent behind this [rake task](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/ab/reindexing-actiontracking/lib/tasks/gitlab/db.rake#L26) is to clean the database objects, so that we're only left with an empty `schema_migrations` table.

Since we are now also using views (e.g. `postgres_indexes`), we need to make sure those are being dropped as well here.

epic.title: Automatic reindexing of standard indexes

title: Heuristic to choose indexes for rebuild
description:
The current approach is to select indexes at random for rebuilds. We can improve that, a few points we discussed are:

1. Choose based on historical bloat levels (based on results of previous rebuilds). Choose indexes with historically high levels of bloat.
1. Choose small indexes first, see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/249662#note_420376511
1. Choose based on rebuild frequency (least frequently rebuilt first)
1. Estimate index bloat and pick highly bloated indexes (by that estimate)
1. Prioritize INVALID indexes to fix those along the way (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/43834#note_421965514)
1. ?

The goal here is to pick a strategy and implement that (one strategy, see how that works out).

epic.title: Automatic reindexing of standard indexes

" -->

An additional search term is no longer needed when searching for a particular filename. 

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

As a developer, when I apply the filename filter, e.g. “filename:*.proto” a search will appear to execute successfully and no results will be returned. When I add in a “*” and execute the query, results will be successfully returned. I think that the first query should return results, or should at least give some indication that it’s an invalid query. 

### Intended users

<!-- Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later.

* [Simone (Software Engineer in Test)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#simone-software-engineer-in-test)
* [Allison (Application Ops)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#allison-application-ops)

* [Dana (Data Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#dana-data-analyst)

Developers and any people that search for specific files. 

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ -->

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

Filetype filters should assume a wildcard search for the contents of no additional query terms are supplied.

It would give a less confusing search experience.

title: Add search time thresholds to handbook
description:
As per the new test for elasticsearch record insertion and recall that suggests bug prioritization on failing (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/39130), we should update the handbook to indicate what those thresholds are so that future test writers can incorporate those thresholds into future tests by looking at the handbook instead of looking at test files.

Thresholds should be added here https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/issue-triage/#severity, of if not there, then we should link to a new page in https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/enablement/search that does have thresholds.

title: Filters params remain when switching tabs
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

Search filters are not cleared when switching to a new result tab.

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- Describe how one can reproduce the issue - this is very important. Please use an ordered list. -->

1. Search for Merge requests in a group, project, or globally (https://gitlab.com/search?group_id=9970&project_id=278964&repository_ref=master&scope=merge_requests&search=test&snippets=false&state=merged)
1. Choose status of `merged` from the Status drop down
1. Change to the Issues tab
1. The URL still contains the filter state which causes the search to not find any results

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

<!-- Describe what actually happens. -->

No results will be found for issues search if a state is selected which is not supported

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

<!-- Describe what you should see instead. -->

Issues search should return results

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

<!-- Paste any relevant logs - please use code blocks (```) to format console output, logs, and code
 as it's tough to read otherwise. -->

Search URL generated by the steps above

https://gitlab.com/search?group_id=9970&project_id=278964&repository_ref=master&scope=issues&search=test&snippets=false&state=merged

Removing the state will return results

https://gitlab.com/search?group_id=9970&project_id=278964&repository_ref=master&scope=issues&search=test&snippets=false

### Possible fixes

<!-- If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem. -->

It's probably a good practice to clear all filters when switching tabs

title: Add API Fuzzing report type to backend
description:
### Problem

Backend doesn't support API Fuzzing reports. This prevents display of API Fuzzing results in the security dashboard.

### Proposal

Add new report type to backend for API Fuzzing.

Report type: `api_fuzzing`
Default filename: `gl-api-fuzzing-report.json`

Tasks:

1. [x] Add new plan type column https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/43934
1. [x] Document new db field
1. [x] Add new report type to backend
1. [x] Update graphql schema
1. [x] Add/update tests

title: Highlight MR diffs that are too large to be shown
description:
Similar to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/16047, this issue aims to visually emphasize hidden diffs in merge requests, to avoid users missing them altogether, especially when they need to be reviewed.

This case is scoped to **diffs that are too large to be shown**, and the user must navigate to the file directly to view the changes.

### Proposal

Reusing the design proposed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/16047:
1. Title: `Changes are too large to be shown.`
1. Button: `View file @ {SHA}`
1. Background: `$orange-50`
1. Button variant: Default

![image](/uploads/a966c04f9c5e4c74f53010db0eeebbc5/image.png)

epic.title: Improve hidden diffs in merge requests

description:

### Problem to solve

As part of https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4491 ,  we need a way for system administrators to approve users that have requested access to an instance. 

### Intended users

* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)

https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 


### Proposal

In the user details screen that can be accessed via the admin panel, show a panel if the user is pending approval. 

"This user has requested access"

" Approved users can
* Sign in.
* Access Git repositories.
* Be a member of groups and projects."

" Approve User"

Once approved, this panel goes away and the user is moved out of the pending approval state.

Will be similar to the other panels already shown.

![Screen_Shot_2020-09-28_at_9.56.14_AM](/uploads/99dd19bc87e597c62cd574166fc7d7da/Screen_Shot_2020-09-28_at_9.56.14_AM.png)

title: Remove GraphQL GlobalIDType compatibility layer
description:
In !36209 a compatibility layer was introduced to allow us to change the types
of arguments from `ID_TYPE` to `GlobalIDType[T]`. This requires us to be careful and add
lots of explicit coercions. 

This issue is for the removal of the compatibility layer once
the deprecation cycle has been run, and all stakeholders informed.

### During %"14.8" 

Manage deprecation: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/352832

- [x] Update the deprecation list including this changes https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/update/deprecations.html
  - see: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/merge_requests/80636
- [x] Update the milestone to %"14.10" 


### During %"14.10" or %"15.0"

- [x] Remove the compatibility layer introduced in !36209, which overrides
      the type equality check.
- [x] Remove all the explicit coercions, marked where possible with TODOs
- [ ] Ensure arguments are `required:` as appropriate (see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/46491#note_439169712)

Welcome to GitLab!

Hi (name),

Your GitLab account request has been approved!

The next four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended in your first draft, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution.
### Release notes 

What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

### Problem to solve

As part of https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4491 , we want to create a new status where users can be placed before they are accepted by administrators. 



### Intended users


* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)


### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 


### Proposal

Create a new status "blocked_pending_approval". 

When a user is in this status:
* Make sure that `User#blocked?` also considers this value. That happens at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/7171cae11384b3dd3f1f90bbcd7a4b7e47b570fb/app/models/user.rb#L313
* A user in this state should not be able to log in. 
* Only an instance admin should be able to change the user out of this state.
* An error message should be shown if they try to log in or recover their password. "Your account registration is awaiting approval. Please contact your system administrator for more details".
* The user should not count as a billable seat.
* If https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/257881 is enabled, then when a user registers they will be placed in this state after registration. They'll receive this message in the UI after they complete registration "Your account registration is awaiting approval. Please contact your system administrator for more details".

title: Limit reindexing concurrency
description:
We aim to start a cronjob for `rake gitlab:db:reindex` once every hour. Even if the operation takes longer, we need to make sure there is only ever one reindexing operation running at a moment (this is a resource guard).

In this issue, we add a locking mechanic to the rake task to make sure we limit its concurrency.

Jira DVCS connection has wrong oauth scope
description:
When connecting Jira via DVCS following the [setup documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/integration/jira_development_panel.html#jira-dvcs-connector-setup) it shows an error saying:
> The requested scope is invalid, unknown, or malformed.

The requested scope is `repo` but should be `api`.

Connecting with GitLab via DVCS is not officially supported by Jira. We use the GitHub enterprise link to connect. Maybe the scopes in GitHub enterprise had changed recently.

title: ClusterReindexingService is stuck in a loop if task was lost
description:
This issue was [reported](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/34069#note_419446819) by a customer.

If during the reindexing process elasticsearch cluster failed for some reason, the reindexing process will stuck in a loop. The main issue with this is that indexing will remain paused and self-managed admin won't be able to trigger another reindexing.

When trying to load such reindexing task info we receive 404

```shell
$ curl -XGET 'http://localhost:9200/_tasks/-bRdhZ5ZT421rVk6JJLJ0w:37882'
{"error":{"root_cause":[{"type":"resource_not_found_exception","reason":"task [-bRdhZ5ZT421rVk6JJLJ0w:37882] isn't running and hasn't stored its results"}],"type":"resource_not_found_exception","reason":"task [-bRdhZ5ZT421rVk6JJLJ0w:37882] isn't running and hasn't stored its results"},"status":404}
```

title: Remove the `container_registry_fast_tag_delete` feature flag
description:
## Summary

The `container_registry_fast_tag_delete` ~"feature flag" was introduced with https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/23325. No tracking issue was found but we have this report issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/195481. The ~"feature flag" was introduced in %12.8.

Given that it is enabled by default, it should be safe to remove it.

## Improvements

* One less ~"feature flag" to manage

## Risks

* Low. This feature flag controls if the delete tags service will use a faster container registry API for tags deletion. This API is *only* available on the GitLab container registry fork.
  * This API presence is now checked directly by [the container client](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/container_registry/client.rb#L82-87)

## Involved components

* [DeleteTagsService](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/services/projects/container_repository/delete_tags_service.rb) and the related spec
* The feature flag [config file](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/config/feature_flags/development/container_registry_fast_tag_delete.yml).

### Problem to solve

Currently the usage ping only [reports](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage_data.rb#L137) the total number of packages present within the system.

We could have better insights if we have this count broken down [package types](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/models/packages/package.rb#L49). For example, when implementing an MVC for a feature that is linked to a package type, these counts could indicate which package type should we start with.

title: Optimise Notes::CopyService SQL queries
description:
#### Problem

`Notes::CopyService` does not perform well when called from `Issues::MoveService` and `DesignManagement::CopyDesignCollection::CopyService`. 

See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/41714#note_419395864 for a description of the problem.

#### Proposal

Looks for ways to reduce the number of SQL queries.

Also see this comment from `@alexkalderimis`: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/44662#note_426534106 as something to perhaps explore.

### Backlog Refinement Notes

the aim is to improve performance rather than eliminate all problems (`Notes::CopyService` has been in the wild for a while now, refactored from code that was essentially the same, so any issues are not new) and we could focus on the low-hanging fruit.

If we discover more complicated problems (that are important to address) we could generate issues for them.

Looking at the queries in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/41714#note_419395864 it does seem like some of it is N+1 queries, so I agree with Luke to focus on that in this issue.

title: Milestones page broken on dark mode
Audit Event availability for all roles
description:
## Overview
Audit Events (https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/audit_events.html#audit-events) is available for Owners (and Maintainers at the project-level) and not presented in the UI for other roles. This limits the number of users who are able to access this feature.

In order to increase usage of this, we could consider opening up Audit Events for all users - but only presenting audit events for the current user for users below Owner/Maintainer.

## Proposal
For instances/groups/projects eligible to use Audit Events, present Audit Events in the UI for all users.
* At the group level, a non-member/Guest/Reporter/Developer/Maintainer should be able to open Audit Events but only see their own Audit Events. They should not be able to search for events from other members.
* At the project level, this same behavior should apply to non-members/Guest/Reporter/Developer roles.

## Technical implementation

~backend 

1. Remove admin-only authentication to the audit events api ([Project](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/controllers/projects/audit_events_controller.rb#L11), [Group](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/controllers/groups/audit_events_controller.rb#L11))

~frontend 
1. Update the Settings navbar to expose the Audit Events link to all users: ([Project](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/views/layouts/nav/sidebar/_project.html.haml#L425), [Group](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/helpers/groups_helper.rb#L24)).
2. In case of non-admin users, pass the `author_id` in the audit events api ([Project](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/views/projects/sidebar/_settings_audit_events.html.haml#L4), [Group](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/views/groups/ee/_settings_nav.html.haml#L23))

title: Regular Expression Denial of Service in Elastic search results
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

<!-- Summarize the bug encountered concisely. -->

The code in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/26962cded7d44900f7aab0d93b7095e3d518e1bb/ee/lib/gitlab/elastic/search_results.rb#L121 uses a regular expression to strip off the extension from file paths returned in search results.

```ruby
      def self.parse_search_result(result, project)
        ref = result["_source"]["blob"]["commit_sha"]
        path = result["_source"]["blob"]["path"]
        extname = File.extname(path)
        basename = path.sub(/#{extname}$/, '')
```

This basically allows a user to control the regular expression being ran and create a regex with [catastrophic backtracking](https://regular-expressions.mobi/catastrophic.html) on purpose.

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- Describe how one can reproduce the issue - this is very important. Please use an ordered list. -->

It goes without saying that we should not test this on prod.

1. If it isn't done already, [enable Elasticsearch integration](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/integration/elasticsearch.html)
1. Create a project
1. Create a file named `aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaab.(a+)+$` with content `SEARCH_ME_REGEX_DOS_ISSUE`
1. Search for `SEARCH_ME_REGEX_DOS_ISSUE`
1. Request times out and fails with 500 error, process uses 100% CPU

Performance on my self-hosted GitLab was degraded and spamming a few of those requests could probably do some damage to uptime.

Here's a mocked example of what happens

```ruby
# Faked result
path = '/group/project/aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaab.(a+)+$'

# Code from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/26962cded7d44900f7aab0d93b7095e3d518e1bb/ee/lib/gitlab/elastic/search_results.rb#L120-121
extname = File.extname(path)
basename = path.sub(/#{extname}$/, '')
```

This code never returns.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

<!-- Describe what actually happens. -->

DoS caused by catastrophic backtracking of the regular expression

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

<!-- Describe what you should see instead. -->

Extension being stripped without performance issues

### Output of checks

Found in the master branch, probably happens on GitLab.com but I didn't test for obvious reasons.

### Possible fixes

<!-- If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem. -->

```diff
diff --git a/ee/lib/gitlab/elastic/search_results.rb b/ee/lib/gitlab/elastic/search_results.rb
index dc8da0e2e05..cb0c0e0fd11 100644
--- a/ee/lib/gitlab/elastic/search_results.rb
+++ b/ee/lib/gitlab/elastic/search_results.rb
@@ -117,8 +117,7 @@ module Gitlab
       def self.parse_search_result(result, project)
         ref = result["_source"]["blob"]["commit_sha"]
         path = result["_source"]["blob"]["path"]
-        extname = File.extname(path)
-        basename = path.sub(/#{extname}$/, '')
+        basename = File.join(File.dirname(path), File.basename(path, File.extname(path)))
         content = result["_source"]["blob"]["content"]
         project_id = result['_source']['project_id'].to_i
         total_lines = content.lines.size
```

If we must use the regex solution for whatever reason, then the regex should be constructed like so `/#{Regexp.escape(extname)}$/`.

title: 'dotenv: report' artifacts replaced by newly run pipelines on the same commit ref
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

Unable to run pipelines off of the same commit, with out having the dotenv report artifact be replaced by the most recent run pipeline.
Previous run pipelines download incorrect dotenv artifacts via their Needs: jobs.

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- Describe how one can reproduce the issue - this is very important. Please use an ordered list. -->

### Example Project

<!-- If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic 
behavior, and link to it here in the bug report. If you are using an older version of GitLab, this 
will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version. -->

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

A dotenv report job is created in a Parent Pipeline (Pipeline A). to pass variables to downstream (child) pipelines within the same project.

In the downstream (Child) pipelines, the dotenv job is accessed via a 'Needs:' job for the project/job name/ref (branch)

If a new pipeline (Pipeline B) is run from the same commit, naturally it will create a dotenv Job with the same Job Name, from that same commit, in its own pipeline.

The issue is, Pipeline A's dotenv artifact has now been replaced by Pipeline B's artifact
Any in progress / future pipeline A jobs will now download the wrong artifact via its Needs: job, and will fail due to invalid variables expected from Pipeline A's dotenv job.


### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Pipeline A creates a dotenv report job. 
Downstream pipelines (child pipelines) downloads the dotenv artifact via a Needs: job, that is tied to the $CI_PIPELINE_ID, not the Ref (branch or commit).

This would allow multiple pipelines to be run from the same project / branch / commit, with different variables passed in the dotenv report.

**Current:**
```
upstreamVariables:
  stage: createVariables
  environment:
    name: $CI_COMMIT_BRANCH
  tags:
    - win_pwsh
  needs:
  - project: $CI_PROJECT_PATH
    job: downstreamVariables
    ref: $CI_COMMIT_BRANCH
    artifacts: true
  script:
    - write-host "This Deployment was triggered via '$CI_PARENT_SOURCE', from the '$CI_COMMIT_BRANCH' branch, and is using the '.upstreamVariables' job" `n -ForegroundColor Green
  artifacts:
    reports:
      dotenv: dotenv.txt
```

**Proposed:**
```
upstreamVariables:
  stage: createVariables
  environment:
    name: $CI_COMMIT_BRANCH
  tags:
    - win_pwsh
  needs:
  - project: $CI_PROJECT_PATH
    job: downstreamVariables
    ref: **_$CI_PIPELINE_ID_**
    artifacts: true
  script:
    - write-host "This Deployment was triggered via '$CI_PARENT_SOURCE', from the '$CI_COMMIT_BRANCH' branch, and is using the '.upstreamVariables' job" `n -ForegroundColor Green
  artifacts:
    reports:
      dotenv: dotenv.txt
```


With the 'needs' job depending on the 'ref', it will pull the existing dotenv job artifact it finds on that commit, with the specified job name, rather then the job name for the intended Pipeline.

This would allow multiple dotenv report artifacts to exist, 1 for each pipeline, not one for the entire project / branch / commit, that when pulled, determines what variables you get (Artifact)

### Possible fixes

**Proposed:**
```
upstreamVariables:
  stage: createVariables
  environment:
    name: $CI_COMMIT_BRANCH
  tags:
    - win_pwsh
  needs:
  - project: $CI_PROJECT_PATH
    job: downstreamVariables
    ref: **_$CI_PIPELINE_ID_**
    artifacts: true
  script:
    - write-host "This Deployment was triggered via '$CI_PARENT_SOURCE', from the '$CI_COMMIT_BRANCH' branch, and is using the '.upstreamVariables' job" `n -ForegroundColor Green
  artifacts:
    reports:
      dotenv: dotenv.txt
```

## Proposal

To narrow down the scope of looking for artifacts for a specific job name we can introduce a new `needs:pipeline` syntax that allows downloading artifacts from a given pipeline ID.

```yaml
build_job:
  needs:
    - pipeline: $CI_UPSTREAM_PIPELINE_ID
      job: $DEPENDENCY_JOB_NAME
      artifacts: true 
```

Upstream pipelines can pass their ID via `trigger:variables` in the bridge job and the downstream pipeline can use that ID to reference the right version of the artifact.

title: Allow us to record conversion events for experiment participants
description:
Adding on to the basic concept outlined in #255615 of knowing if a user has performed the desired conversion action for an experiment or not, we would also like to know _when_ the user performed that action (especially as it relates to when they first joined the experiment).

To keep track of this historical data, we will add a `converted_at` timestamp column (e.g. `2020-09-25 17:11:42 +0000`) to the `experiment_users` database table. Before the conversion event the value would simply be `NULL` (and the corresponding value in the `converted` boolean column would be `false`). After they perform the conversion event, the value of the `converted_at` column will be stamped with the time of the conversion event (and the corresponding value in the `converted` boolean column would get updated to `true`). Then we can do comparisons with the already-present `created_at` timestamp column in the `experiment_users` table to see how long it took from when the user initially joined the experiment to when they performed the desired conversion event.

epic.title: Record Experiment Data

title: Undesirable effect of "Skip outdated deployment jobs" CI feature on manual jobs + related stages
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

[Customer](https://gitlab.my.salesforce.com/0014M00001in3W2QAI) raised a [ticket](https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/173413) (internal links) because there were getting slack notifications for deployment jobs failing. 

The jobs were failing in historic pipelines, and related to deployments that were never run.

Customer uses manual deployment jobs.

Investigation showed that, depending on how pipeline was configured, the effect of leaving this feature enabled (which is the default) can put historic pipelines into some odd states.

[Docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/pipelines/settings.html#skip-outdated-deployment-jobs) for skip outdated deployment jobs state "The pending deployment jobs will be skipped." - this doesn't happen in the case of manual jobs.  Mostly, manual jobs cease to be undeployed manual jobs, and are switched to a failed state, and the stages in the pipeline can switch from blocked or manual to running or failed.

However, there's a number of outcomes possible, as shown in the examples, potentially all within the same pipeline.

<!-- Summarize the bug encountered concisely. -->

### Workaround

[Disable skip outdated deployment jobs on the project](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/pipelines/settings.html#skip-outdated-deployment-jobs)

Set ~"severity::3"  

### Steps to reproduce / Example Project

Example CI attached along with screenshots below.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Manual jobs are set failed, stages in pipelines get switched to 'running' (or maybe 'pending' states) - the treatment can vary for environments in the same pipeline; eg: see example 3.

The purpose of this feature seems to prevent multiple live pipelines deploying to the same environment in the wrong order. If an earlier pipeline tries to deploy old code to an environment, it should get skipped.

This doesn't really apply to manual jobs.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Either don't change manual jobs, or set them skipped.
Skipped also removes the play button, reducing the chance of accidental deployment.

See example 3 for a CI config where 1/3 manual deploy jobs are left undeployed, 1/3 set failed, and 1/3 set skipped.  So this feature does sometimes set manual jobs skipped.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

* The example CI only runs deployments after a merge request.
* In each example, changes to the project are made twice, and merged, triggering the full CI config twice.
* The first time, no deployments are run, for example:

![image](/uploads/5d770f92f561e9fd8e9960ffadd076c9/image.png)

* The second time, all deployments are run, eg:

![image](/uploads/68bd5e5d5db786b3e4b952c0a02afe23/image.png)

* This issue relates to what happens as a result to the earlier pipeline.

* The status of the first pipeline is shown in both its original state, and the revised state after the subsequent deployment.

#### example 1

* [gitlab-ci.yml](/uploads/a55b1b4dd72cb185028d486b500394d3/gitlab-ci.yml)
* Summary before: ![image](/uploads/e3134b5ac7b7a430e1c8733b56cf3a82/image.png) after: ![image](/uploads/54e57da631cc07f7579f3bc367c29b98/image.png)

<details>
<summary>before/after detail</summary>

- initial deployment

![image](/uploads/471c8d1dd439ca6563cbed725bf279a1/image.png)

![image](/uploads/5d770f92f561e9fd8e9960ffadd076c9/image.png)

- after subsequent deployment

![image](/uploads/85958981dfcab850046b72ba6cab43e1/image.png)

![image](/uploads/043137b2b6a6bffbf237f58bf0648a30/image.png)


</details>

#### example 2

* [gitlab-ci.yml](/uploads/97dfbd35a6bdbd01dd25c3770b3d5834/gitlab-ci.yml)
* Summary before: ![image](/uploads/0bca06bb9ba634eee78e42daf1f86b57/image.png) after: ![image](/uploads/ff4bfbf49bbc30351cd6208c1dacb270/image.png)

<details>
<summary>before/after detail</summary>

- initial deployment

![image](/uploads/af97b244199f3af5ddf67acfc67410c8/image.png)

![image](/uploads/66d32186d2a981a25a00489da516a901/image.png)

- after subsequent deployment

![image](/uploads/2942543d8557c45098338f0e0d8f1611/image.png)

![image](/uploads/c692cf5b437809fd6ecb656be9caac39/image.png)


</details>

#### Example 3

This was from earlier in the testing, before the test case was simplified.

This produces an outcome where one of the deploy jobs is skipped, then the stage goes into 'pending' because there's another job in that stage that would normally run once the previous stage is deployed.

* ci [gitlab-ci.yml](/uploads/ecae349bc2b8da40f5d81534b5bf9c6c/gitlab-ci.yml)
* Summary before: ![image](/uploads/15b5e398f269887461996d3567ee1091/image.png) after: ![image](/uploads/071541bbf077a91e734ba47e83f8b0d2/image.png)

<details>
<summary>before/after detail</summary>

- initial deployment

![image](/uploads/05feed1eabe649084e1c51e91fcf7572/image.png)

![image](/uploads/0587ec1e0fff5cc61372ded843cc1c57/image.png)

- after subsequent deployment

![image](/uploads/c7479417985205eda4c8c1d406e0b0f8/image.png)

![image](/uploads/4c8b603b9d9dab984a8974e986d4af59/image.png)
</details>

#### failed job status

To complete the account of what happens, the job page displays the following:

![image](/uploads/64610234d02f165f427f775d0249a7c3/image.png)

Full text so it's searchable:

```
The deployment job is older than the previously succeeded deployment job, and therefore cannot be run
The deployment of this job to stg did not succeed.
```

### Output of checks

#### Results of GitLab environment info

- Customer reported issue on gitlab.com;  13.5.0-pre 417adc72d64
- Reproduced on 13.3.5 self managed


### Possible fixes

title: [VSA] Cancel button disabled when editing a stage
description:
### Problem to solve

Group-level Value Stream Analytics allows users to edit the stages.  Currently, when editing a stage, the "Cancel" button is disabled and it's not clear why.  (This was originally reported at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/249803#cancel-is-disabledwhy.)

### Proposal

The "Cancel" button should always be enabled, and when clicked should simply close the "edit" interface.

### Screenshot

![Screen_Shot_2020-09-25_at_1.18.36_PM](/uploads/71033edb237d53b0409d37f969e054a2/Screen_Shot_2020-09-25_at_1.18.36_PM.png)
