title: Confirmation panels for significant actions are inconsistent in text to type in
description:
### Summary

Some actions like deleting a project and transferring a project to another namespace require the user to confirm the action by typing in a piece of text. For deleting projects, the user is asked to type in `Delete` followed by the full namespace and project title. For transferring a project, the user is asked to just type in the project's name (as opposed to title), without the namespace.

I think these and other confirmation panels should be consistent in what they ask users to type in. Additionally, asking users to type the full namespace and title is way too long. The attached screenshots show an example where I would have to type in `Delete Enverus / Business Automation / Cluster Support / Deploy Services`, a 72 character long piece of text. It's even worse with deeper group hierarchies or longer project titles.

### Steps to reproduce

Perform an action that requires confirmation, like deleting a project or transferring a project to a new namespace.

### Example Project

N/A

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The requested confirmation string differs between panels, and is sometimes unreasonably long.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

All the confirmation panels should be consistent in what they ask the user to type in. I would personally prefer just the project's name (i.e., last path component, equivalent to `$CI_PROJECT_NAME`).

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

**Delete project**:

![Screen_Shot_2020-09-25_at_11.49.11_AM](/uploads/70eacf89ac060a0d9c312cb8afcdbf64/Screen_Shot_2020-09-25_at_11.49.11_AM.png)

**Transfer project**:

![Screen_Shot_2020-09-25_at_11.49.42_AM](/uploads/8d4ff9959023a4de8cbbaed01c176265/Screen_Shot_2020-09-25_at_11.49.42_AM.png)

### Output of checks

This happens on GitLab.com.

#### Results of GitLab environment info

N/A

#### Results of GitLab application Check

N/A

### Possible fixes

Choose a consistent thing to ask the user to type in. I suggest just the project name (not the title).

title: Create visual concepts of subscription management
description:
We will move subscription management into the .com application. We might also move this into .com for self-managed customers, but this is tentative.

In order to uncover technical and user experience questions and better communicate the vision, we need some visual concepts of how this could look.

These aren't final designs - they should be rough and highly imperfect, perhaps not even full sized, most likely in a rough wireframe or sketch form. We want to communicate information architecture, user flow and high level page structure only.

We can base these on current assumptions and knowledge but call out anywhere we aren't sure how to proceed - so those areas can get further research as needed.

### Subscription management

* Upgrading existing subscription
* View information about existing subscription
* Add new services
* Update contact information
* Update information relevant to invoices
* Make a payment
* Add/edit a payment method
* View invoices and balance
* View past and predictive usage related to subscription


## Sketches / wireframes
- [Video walkthrough](https://www.loom.com/share/dfe74ca63fbf49d1ad803a0e79e365ad)
- [Figma link](https://www.figma.com/file/Ql1Cqokfkq5b9bjUAra54F/Subscription-management-in-GitLab.com?node-id=0%3A1)

## Next steps

With the information architecture we've outlined in this issue, we can move forward with wireframes and designs for each of the pages and flows that we've identified. In each of the below issues, we'll be taking the rough wireframes that we've created here and flesh them out into more detailed wireframes and then final designs.

- [Navigation for subscription management pages](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/333949)
     - This will also include a solution validation issue, which will be created once we've determined a proposed solution
- [Subscription & purchases page](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/333823) (will replace the Billing page)
     - [Add seats flow](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/333824)
     - [Upgrade flow](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/333825)
     - [Renew flow](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/331320)
- [Account info page](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/333948)


#### Handling edge cases

All of the above issues will handle wireframes and designs for the primary use cases. We also have edge cases, most notably the EoA Bronze customer experience. I've created separate issues for those. As we identify additional edge cases, we'll create issues for those too.

- [Subscription & purchases page for Bronze customers](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/333952)
     - [Upgrade flow for Bronze customers](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/333950)
     - [Renew flow for Bronze customers](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/333954)

epic.title: [UX] Move subscription management to gitlab.com

title: Limit the number identifiers associated with a finding
description:
Currently, there is no limit on how many identifiers a finding can have.

If a finding has hundreds of identifiers, serializing them into one CSV column will make it harder to navigate for the end-user. It could also potentially break the UI as we don't test findings with more than a few associations.

This was a feedback of the maintainer here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/43179#note_418720058

## Implementation Plan

- [ ] ~documentation Document in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/doc/development/integrations/secure.md#L354 that you cannot have more than 20 identifiers in security report and only first 20 identifiers will be saved into finding.
- [ ] ~backend In `StoreReportService` (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/417ccb03d9b72022af1539541d5b408cb78d55c0/ee/app/services/security/store_report_service.rb#L57) limit saved identifiers to max 20 (set and use the constant in `Vulnerabilities::FindingIdentifier` model)

title: Separate GraphQL Grafana dashboard
description:
Currently, the only view onto GraphQL we have in Grafana is the [`api: Rails Controller` dashboard](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/api-rails-controller/api-rails-controller?orgId=1&var-controller=GraphqlController&var-action=All). This aggregates over all GraphQL queries.

We should probably have more fine-grained views for this, since the characteristics for different queries could be very different.

## Proposal

Add a dashboard that will be placeholder for GraphQL-related panels. Start with a single text panel describing what the dashboard is used for, reference the [GraphQL API observability blueprint](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/architecture/blueprints/graphql_api/).

Add a second panel with GraphQL controller / execute action request rate per second.

epic.title: Grafana dashboard for GraphQL API

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of `schema_linting`
description:
## Summary

This issue is to rollout the feature on production, that is currently behind the `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag.

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::editor"  
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_create_editor`
- Best individual to reach out to: @dmishunov 
- PM: @ericschurter 

## Stakeholders

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

### When is the feature viable?

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

_Consider mentioning checks for 5xx errors or other anomalies like an increase in redirects (302 HTTP response status)_

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

_Consider adding links to check for Sentry errors, Production logs for 5xx, 302s, etc._

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

* [x] Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
  * [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
* [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
  * [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --dev --staging --staging-ref`
* [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable. The best environment to validate the feature in is [staging-canary](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/#staging-canary) as this is the first environment deployed to. Note you will need to make sure you are configured to use canary as outlined [here](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/canary-stage/) when accessing the staging environment in order to make sure you are testing appropriately.

### Specific rollout on production

* [x] Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
  * [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
  * If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    * [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab,gitlab-org/gitlab-foss,gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
  * If you're using [group-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    * [ ] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org,gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
  * If you're using [user-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    * [ ] `/chatops run feature set --user=<your-username> <feature-flag-name> true`
* [x] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

* [x] Set a milestone to the rollout issue to signal for enabling and removing the feature flag when it is stable.
* [x] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process). Cross link the issue here if it does.
* [x] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production. If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
* [x] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
* [x] Leave a comment on the feature issue announcing estimated time when this feature flag will be enabled on GitLab.com.
* [x] Ensure that any breaking changes have been announced following the [release post process](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#deprecations-removals-and-breaking-changes) to ensure GitLab customers are aware.
* [x] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

* [x] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  * [ ] If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    * [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --actors`
    * If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
      * [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --random`
    * Enable the feature globally on production environment.
      * [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true`
* [x] Leave a comment on the feature issue announcing that the feature has been globally enabled.
* [x] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release) but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled. To do so, follow these steps:

* [x] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
  * [x] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
  * [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
* [x] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been included in the release package. If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1), the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
  * [x] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
* [x] Consider cleaning up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel. Otherwise these settings may override the default enabled.
  * [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
* [x] Close the feature issue to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
* [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
* [x] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
  * [x] Set the title to "\[Feature flag\] Cleanup `<feature-flag-name>`".
  * [x] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
  * [x] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
  * [x] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag. For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release), the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

* [ ] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
  * [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
  * [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
  * [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
* [ ] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been included in the release package. If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1), the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
  * [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
* [ ] Close the feature issue to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
* [ ] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
  * [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
* [ ] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

* [x] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> false
```

title: Persist Swimlane Setting
description:
As part of &3352 we need to persist the user's choice of grouping on a specific board.

Currently this is limited to epics (for epic swimlanes). However the value could also be `null`; i.e. no swimlanes enabled on the board.

#### Current behaviour

- When viewing an issue board, a user can elect to group issues into swimlanes by epic;
- They do this by clicking on the "Group by" dropdown and selecting "Epic", and
- This change is not persisted, if they refresh the page they see no grouping.

![image](/uploads/1aea8eb6e2768bc31d7a65f2be6f9ead/image.png)

#### Expected behaviour

- The change is persisted on the backend and the selection remains when the page is refreshed.

#### Other solutions

A better solution might be to persist state in the URL (see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/218348#note_418620713) so that it can be shared. This may be out of scope for the first iteration, however.

title: Reduce time taken to scan target applications
description:
### Problem to solve

Browserker scans take a long time to run. How can we make them faster?

### Proposal

Possible things to investigate:
- Instrumenting Browserker code to understand where the time in the application is spent
- "Cheating" by continuing paths instead of starting again
- Modifying the `BrowserPool` so that browsers can be leased from browsers running on a different Docker container/CI job
- Attacking while scanning

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

DAST has more understanding of why a scan is slow, and what can be done to improve it.

### What is the type of buyer?

[Gold/Ultimate](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/pricing/#four-tiers)

title: Document how to use DAST Browserker mode
description:
### Problem to solve

Once Browserker is ready to use as an alpha feature in DAST, the GitLab DAST documentation should be updated to instruct users how to run a Browserker scan.

### Proposal

Update the GitLab documentation to:
- Run a scan with the `DAST_BROWSERKER_SCAN` environment variable
- Roughly describe how the scan works, and for what situations it is expected to return better results
- Describe the environment variables that can be used to configure Browserker (see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/issues/5)
- Make it clear that the feature is "~~alpha~~" "beta" and is subject to change
- Use the User Guide written by @idawson https://docs.google.com/document/d/1x9WipjoQjUoWYf2bWj2UucDikB-zD2YrhKXNQnbsGho/edit# (internal) as a starting place

### Requests from Technical Writers

- Add the Browserker configuration to a new page, not to https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dast/
- https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dast/ will link to the Browserker configuration page
- Don’t use a structure that has a FAQ, find some other way to communicate the same message
- Structure the new Browserker configuration page as What, Why and How
  - What is Browserker, Why would I use it, How do I use it: enable it, run it, analyse the output?
  - Note that the “What” and “Why” should be the introduction to the Browserker page. Don’t insert “What” and “Why” as titles
- The DAST page should remain as-is, though there will be a need to include mentions of Browserker, and link to its own page
- Maybe add mention of Browserker to the DAST introduction, then factor a decision about it into `Enable DAST`
- Maybe include a feature comparison table for current DAST vs Browserker? A table like that coveys the necessary info easily and requires the fewest words.


### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Users understand how to use Browserker and can configure a scan without a GitLab engineer's support.

### What is the type of buyer?

[Gold/Ultimate](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/pricing/#four-tiers)

title: Snowplow tracking event value property must be a decimal
description:
There are a few places in our documentation and in the code where we are not properly specifying or enforcing the fact that the `value` property of a [Snowplow structured event](https://github.com/snowplow/snowplow/wiki/2-Specific-event-tracking-with-the-Javascript-tracker#trackStructEvent) (via `window.snowplow('trackStructEvent', …)` or `Gitlab::Tracking.event(…)`) must be of type decimal (i.e. an integer or float).

In order to be consistent with ourselves and to provide developers with the most accurate information, we should fix it in the following places:

- [x] Fix (or remove) default `value` getting set in [`tracking.js`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/tracking.js)
  - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/v13.4.1-ee/app/assets/javascripts/tracking.js#L19-20

title: Cannot add two comments on same line during merge request review with "inline" diff view
description:
### Summary

When performing a merge request "Review" and using the "inline" diff view, it is currently impossible to add a second comment to a line that already contains a pending comment. The input box for the second comment renders *behind* the pending comment already on that line. Switching to the "side-by-side" diff view allows for adding the second comment. However, once the second comment is added to the review, it then renders its pending comment *on top of* the original pending comment for that line, making it impossible to edit the first comment later on in the review.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open a merge request's changes in the "inline" diff view.
1. Write a comment for a changed line and click "Start a review".
1. Click the comment bubble on the same line number to attempt to add a second comment for that line.
1. Observe that no input box is visible.

### Example Project

The behavior happens in the Gitlab project: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab ([Test MR](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/43357/diffs?view=inline))

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

In the "inline" diff view, the input box for a second comment renders *behind* the pending comment already on that line.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The input box should render *above* the pending comment already on that line.

### Relevant info and screenshots

First screenshot below shows the state immediately after clicking the comment bubble to add a second comment to line 263, which already has a pending comment. Notice the thin white line directly above the yellow-shaded pending comment. That thin white line is the input box rendering behind the original pending comment.

![image](/uploads/2fbb3a38851979cae14bbbeffa9761e8/image.png)

---

Second screenshot below shows the same state as above, but in the "side-by-side" diff view. Notice the input box rendering above the original pending comment for that line.

![image](/uploads/d308338497abf505dcc080d7453c85b7/image.png)

---

Third screenshot below shows the state immediately after clicking the "Add to review" button for the second comment in "side-by-side" view. Notice the new pending comment rendering on top of the original pending comment, hiding the original comment and making it impossible to edit the original comment.

![image](/uploads/2b204667b50569ff67ef7f60014d756f/image.png)

---

##### Version info

- Browser – Chrome Version 85.0.4183.102 (Official Build) (64-bit)
- OS – Windows 10 Build 1709

epic.title: Record Experiment Data

title: Add converted (boolean) column to the experiment_users table
description:
For the most basic form of A/B testing we really need to record whether or not the user performed the desired action (i.e. converted).

Let’s add a boolean column to the `experiment_users` table which defaults to `false` and gets updated to `true` when the user converts.

We will also need to create some simple helper methods for updating the row for an existing `user_id` & `experiment_id` combination.

## How it works

Here’s a rough idea of how adding such a column will give us much better insights using [the “group-only trials” experiment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/215852) as an example:

1. User arrives on the “select your namespace” step of the “start a trial” flow (i.e. `/-/trails/select`)
   - We know who this user is (i.e. we have a `user` record and can store their unique & constant `user.id` value) because they had to sign in or register to get this far
   - We immediately record them as being part of the experiment; that is to say, we insert a new row into the `experiment_users` table:
     
     | `id` | `experiment_id` | `user_id` | `group_type` | `converted`   |
     |------|-----------------|-----------|--------------|---------------|
     | `38` | `4`             | `10872`   | `1` (experimental) | `FALSE` |
     
     - Notice that we mark them as not having converted (because they really haven’t done anything yet, they’re just part of the experiment so far)
1. At any point in the future (it doesn’t have to be during this request or session, it doesn’t have to be in the same browser or on the same device) the user follows through with picking a namespace and starting their trial (by clicking on the “Start your free trial” button with a valid namespace selected)
   - As soon as that happens, we update their same row in the `experiment_users` table to specify that they have converted

     | `id` | `experiment_id` | `user_id` | `group_type` | `converted`  |
     |------|-----------------|-----------|--------------|--------------|
     | `38` | `4`             | `10872`   | `1` (experimental) | `TRUE` |

1. Once the user has converted for a specific experiment, we stop accepting updates for them.

---

This idea was originally mentioned here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229057#note_380221114

title: Delayed deletion of projects by default, to avoid catastrophes
description:
### Update 11 Aug 2021:
Dev for this is complete, the remaining work is this production change request to enable the setting by default on the Gitlab.com instance: gitlab-com/gl-infra/production#5323

----
### Problem to solve

Projects can contain a huge amount of valuable data.  Currently they can be deleted instantly.  If deletion is the result of a mistake or a bug (like https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/40353), it can be catastrophic.

### Proposal

Turn on https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/cascading_settings.html at the instance level and lock it. Provide mechanisms for project owners to immediately delete projects scheduled for deletion. Allow for the immediate re-use of paths from projects that are scheduled for delayed deletion. As a bonus, explore allowing subgroups to specify the duration of the deletion period (maybe so long as it is longer than the default setting at from the parent group/instance).

Old proposal:

<details>
Hard deletion of *all* projects should be preceded by a period of delayed deletion, where the project is no longer visible to users but [can be restored by admins](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/37014).

This is different from, but would rely on the same functionality as, the [delayed deletion setting](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/223013).  This would be followed by implementing [similar functionality for groups](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/241146).
</details>

### Implementation Steps


- [x] #191367 : Support the ability to immediately delete a project scheduled for delayed deletion by navigating to `Project > Settings > Projects` and double confirming hard deletion
- [x] Enable the setting by default for newly created top-level namespaces.
- [x] Add instance setting for delayed deletion (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/67230)
- [x] Ensure instance admins can restore any project within the instance that is scheduled for delayed-deletion.
- [x] Add support for Premium+ Groups to override the default delayed period set at the instance level. Subgroups should look to their nearest ancestor to get the default setting. Consider leveraging the existing work being down to cascade settings in a consistent manner (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/291082)

Possible follow-ups / enhancements:

- [x] #329538 : Enable re-use of Project paths when a project is deleted (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/255449#note_499630633)

### GitLab.com Rollout Steps

- [x] Ensure that [the relevant docs section](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/#enable-delayed-project-removal) is updated.
- [x] Let the Support team know when it happens via `#support_gitlab-com` and additional details like if it's behind a feature flag, it's part of the feature flag process/template, so no additional steps are needed.


### Release Post Notes

Up until now, [delayed project deletion](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/#enable-delayed-project-removal) has been disabled by default on GitLab.com because there has been no way to immediately delete a project when necessary. In this release, we've added an instance setting to enable delayed deletion by default for all new projects. We've also added the ability for projects scheduled for delayed deletion to be immediately, permanently removed. Delayed project deletion is now enabled by default for GitLab.com and leverages our [cascading settings framework](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/cascading_settings.html) so groups can freely opt out of the default behavior if so desired. 

[Documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/#enable-delayed-project-removal)

title: Users unable to edit default network policies
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

<!-- Summarize the bug encountered concisely. -->
Users currently have an odd experience with the policy editor as default / out-of-the-box policies are not able to be edited.  Users will expect the available actions to be consistent across all policies, regardless of whether they are a default / out-of-the-box policy or a policy they have created themselves.

This behavior was intentional because default policies are not actually created until a user enables them; however, the resulting user experience is perceived as a bug.

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- Describe how one can reproduce the issue - this is very important. Please use an ordered list. -->

### Example Project

<!-- If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic 
behavior, and link to it here in the bug report. If you are using an older version of GitLab, this 
will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version. -->

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

<!-- Describe what actually happens. -->
The edit button is unavailable for default, out-off-the-box policies

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

<!-- Describe what you should see instead. -->
Users should see the edit button for all policies, including default ones.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

<!-- Paste any relevant logs - please use code blocks (```) to format console output, logs, and code
 as it's tough to read otherwise. -->

### Possible fixes / Initial Idea

<!-- If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem. -->
An ideal solution would be to create the new policy automatically when users try to edit it.  This will allow the technical limitations to be met while still preserving a consistent user experience.

### Implementation Plan
 - [x] Convert the OOTB policies to [`CiliumNetworkPolicy`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/417c3e118cd6b5cd8bb780feb58263c5a85dcc0f/lib/gitlab/kubernetes/cilium_network_policy.rb)

title: Geo: rake gitlab:geo:check should check current node when the machine does not match any geo_nodes record
description:
### Summary When setting up a new Geo node, it is easy to accidentally end up with the node not able to know which node it is, usually due to mismatch of `GeoNode.current_node_name` and the `name` of the intended `geo_nodes` record. `rake gitlab:geo:check` does not run the check for current node if the node is a secondary or if it cannot find its node (which is exactly the case when we should run the check for current node). This problem impacted this customer https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/173859 We need to ensure that `rake gitlab:geo:check` always runs all *potentially* relevant checks. ### Steps to reproduce ### Example Project ### What is the current *bug* behavior? ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes

title: GraphQL project token does not have access to project
description:
**Summary**

Query for a project returns null when trying to use project token 

**Query** 

```
query { project(fullPath: "projectName") { name }}
```

**Expected**

```
{ data: { project: { name: "projectName" }}}
```

**Actual**

```
{ data: { project: null }}
```

**What works**

- REST API, no problems using a Private-Token header with a project token and my own personal token.
- CURL, using personal token with cURL using an "Authentication: Bearer" header.
- GraphQL, personal token, with the Private-Token OR Authorization header, I can fetch issues without problem.

**What doesn't work**

- If I try to use a project token, with the Private-Token OR Authorization header, to fetch issues with cURL or a node http request, the return result is `data {project: null}}`

basic cURL command used: ```curl 'url' --header "Authorization: Bearer xxxxxx" --header "Content-Type: application/json" --request POST -d '{"query": "query($path: ID!) {project(fullPath: $path){name}}", "variables": {"path": "adb/flow/flowApp"}}'```

When testing, the only thing I did was replace the token.  Otherwise, it was the same command.

Gitlab version: 13.2.1-ee (I know we are behind.  I have no control over that though and I can't find a bug report on this issue, so if this is fixed in a newer version, my apologies)

title: [Backend] Add ability to create/read/update/delete compliance frameworks
description:
Based on the designs/discussion in this [discovery issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/231247) and once the dependent issue (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/251113) has been completed, this issue is to track the development of the Rails controllers to create, edit and assign compliance frameworks to groups.

## To do

- Create GraphQL queries to allow the following at the root-group level:
  - [x] List all compliance frameworks for a namespace - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/47779
  - [x] Introduce compliance framework creation service - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/47909
  - [x] Delete compliance labels - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/48912
  - [ ] ~~Filter a namespace's list of compliance frameworks by a single ID~~ - Separate issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/289846
  - [x] Create group-level compliance labels - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/48250 (In Maintainer Review)
  - [x] Ability to update an existing compliance framework - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/49157
  - ~~Assign them to projects~~ (Moved to [separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/276221))

:bulb: The engineer working on this may want to consider splitting this in to 3 MRs, depending on their preference.

The form for Compliance Framework Labels should have the following fields:

* **Title:** \[ e.g. HIPAA, SOX, Internal, Tech Risk, otherCustomLabelName \]
  * The labels should allow the use of labels that *look* scoped (use of `::`) but should not implement or leverage any scoped label behavior for now.
* **Description:** \[ e.g. "This label should be applied to projects which are regulated by `HIPAA`" \]
* **Background color:** 

## Out of scope:

- [Enforcement / "regulated" toggle](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220190)
- Force Merge (under ~"workflow::solution validation")

## Mockups

|Settings Page|Edit|New|
|---|---|---|
|![Settings___General__New_label_](/uploads/5d4f4448201ed067ea6a776dd4086474/Settings___General__New_label_.png)|![5](/uploads/4f233ffdfd135023b5cc229670dc53ec/5.png)|![2](/uploads/59f6637fc3b335b6276394c67c98868b/2.png)|

## Outstanding questions

- [x] **Root-group level only** [[Discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/255340#note_442552839)]

## Tier

The ability to create/edit/assign **custom** compliance labels is a ~"GitLab Ultimate" feature.

title: 🎨 Design: Separate validation out of site profile creation
description:
## Proposal

- Remove validation options from the site profile screen
- Add `Validate` button to each row in `Site profiles`
- `Validate` opens modal
- Loading spinner on each row while site is validating
- `Validated` text on each validated row
- [`Revoke validation`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/276228) button on each validated row 

Figma file:  https://www.figma.com/file/7CaJqOTOpPEOzkYkoU5bs5/DAST-Ondemand-Profile?node-id=5022%3A6463

title: [Onboarding through issue board] Successful Cleanup
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Experiment Name] Successful Cleanup -->

## Summary

The purpose of this issue is to clean up the experiment code from the [new user onboarding experiment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/224515). The experiment was successful therefore we should roll out the experiment as a permanent change the user experience when signing up for a GitLab.com account.

## Steps

- [x] Determine whether the feature should apply to SaaS and/or self-managed
- [x] Determine whether the feature should apply to EE - and which tiers - and/or Core
- [x] Determine if tracking should be kept as is, removed, or modified.
- [x] Migrate experiment to a default enabled [feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/development.html) for one milestone and add a changelog. Converting to a feature flag can be skipped at the ICs discretion if risk is deemed low with consideration to both SaaS and (if applicable) self managed.
- [ ] Ensure any relevant documentation has been updated.
- [ ] In the next milestone, [remove the feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up).
- [ ] After the flag removal is deployed, [clean up the feature/experiment feature flags](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) by running chatops command in `#production` channel

## Merge Requests

* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/52520
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/52685
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/52905

title: Follow-up from "Show when the last update to seats usage data was in the Billing page"
description:
The following discussion from !42763 should be addressed:

- [ ] @a_luna started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/42763#note_417805581):  (+1 comment)

    > @splattael from your [comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/42763#note_417386218), it seemed like adding more than a happy path spec would be a bit overkill here :upside_down_face: but please let me know if you consider adding other case(s) would be valuable :eyes: :raised_hands_tone2:

@splattael said in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/42763#note_417925178:

> Thanks for adding the spec :bow: It looks good!
> 
> **Non-blocking** I'd love to see a spec which cover the `nil` branch (if the job is not found) because self-managed instances might have persistent Redis.
> 
> Personally, I am huge fan of [Mutation Testing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation_testing) (e.g. https://github.com/mbj/mutant) which probably would have caught this missing spec :sweat_smile:
> 
> I think we could follow-up on this.
